title: How to Use a Sugar Scrub for Glowing Skin

steps.title: Look for a scrub with fine particles.
steps.content: Look for a scrub with fine particles. A coarse sugar scrub can irritate and even tear sensitive skin. Smaller sugar granules are gentler and less abrasive. [2] X Expert Source Diana Yerkes Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 16 April 2019. Brown sugar is one of the softest sugars and works well on your face and body. [3] X Research source Turbinado sugar (also known as raw sugar) tends to have larger particles so if you see it as an ingredient, be aware that it’s a rougher scrub. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Pick a hydrating scrub if you have very dry skin.
steps.content: Pick a hydrating scrub if you have very dry skin. While sugar is naturally a humectant (meaning it locks in moisture), some scrubs are more moisturizing than others. [5] X Research source Choose one with skin-replenishing ingredients like hyaluronic acid, coconut or avocado oil, glycerin, or essential oils if your skin is prone to dehydration.

steps.title: Select a scent based on aromatherapy properties.
steps.content: Select a scent based on aromatherapy properties. Look for scrubs that include essential oils to match your needs. For example, if you're stressed out, a lavender scent is calming. [6] X Expert Source Diana Yerkes Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 16 April 2019. And if you're feeling fatigued, lemon or peppermint scents are energizing. Other popular aromatherapy scents include eucalyptus for clearing your sinuses, patchouli for soothing anxiety, and rosemary for increasing concentration. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Make your own sugar scrub if you're on a budget.
steps.content: Make your own sugar scrub if you're on a budget. Using basic ingredients from your pantry like olive oil, honey, and brown sugar, you can DIY a sugar scrub at home . [8] X Expert Source Diana Yerkes Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 16 April 2019. Whipping up your own sugar scrub means you can control exactly what goes in it, thus avoiding any chemicals or additives that could be harmful to you or the environment.

steps.title: Wet your skin.
steps.content: Wet your skin. Warm water will soften your skin and prepare it for exfoliation. A good rule of thumb is to soak in the tub or stand under the shower for 5 to 10 minutes before you begin scrubbing. Water that’s too hot can dry out your skin. The optimal temperature for your skin is a lukewarm temperature below 105 °F (41 °C) (if your skin is turning red, it’s too hot!). [9] X Research source If you’re going to shave your legs, do so before using the sugar scrub to avoid stinging and irritation. Wash your skin before you scrub to remove sweat, dirt, and makeup. Otherwise scrubbing could push it further into the skin.

steps.title: Massage the scrub into your skin.
steps.content: Massage the scrub into your skin. With gentle pressure, rub the sugar scrub into your skin in a circular motion using the pads of your fingers. [10] X Expert Source Diana Yerkes Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 16 April 2019. This not only sloughs off dead skin, it also boosts circulation and stimulates the production of collagen in your body, a protein that helps fight wrinkles and keeps skin looking young. [11] X Research source Start at the top of your body and work down. Be careful not to scrub too vigorously as it could damage your skin.

steps.title: Rinse with warm water.
steps.content: Rinse with warm water. There’s no need to use shower gel or soap following your scrub. For extra hydration and smoother skin, let the scrub sit on your body for a couple of minutes before rinsing thoroughly.

steps.title: Dry off.
steps.content: Dry off. Gently use a towel to pat your body completely dry.

steps.title: Finish with lotion or body oil.
steps.content: Finish with lotion or body oil. Once you’re dry, apply lotion or body oil to moisturize your newly exfoliated skin. Do this immediately after drying off while your pores are still open and able to absorb the moisturizer easier and faster. [12] X Research source Have a jar of extra virgin coconut oil laying around. It can double as a cheap yet effective moisturizer thanks to its high level of saturated fats. Only use it if you aren’t prone to breaking out. [13] X Research source Always apply sunscreen after exfoliating as your skin is more vulnerable. Use one that's SPF 30 or higher and has broad-spectrum protection. [14] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Repeat once or twice a week.
steps.content: Repeat once or twice a week. Sugar scrubs shouldn’t be part of your daily beauty routine. Over-exfoliating can irritate your skin so aim to use a sugar scrub no more than three times per week at most. [15] X Research source Don’t use a sugar scrub on skin that’s sunburned or highly sensitive. You should also avoid it after any type of medical or cosmetic surgery or after a chemical peel - in both instances, your body is trying to recover from what is essentially a trauma and any harsh scrubbing could prevent proper healing. [16] X Research source
